>>18762524
1. Be a member of whatever card shit your grocer uses to track your ass OR go to walmart if burgerland
2. Use coupons religiously
3. Watch for price reductions on shit about to expire

If at all possible you want to buy in bulk for cheaper, but I know bulk membership eats an extra $50 a year. At least buy in bulk at the supermarket where possible.

If you can eat at your job (because food service), the do so as often as possible.

Eggs are high right now, so stick to cheap protein sources. Four, sugar, rice, beans, dried pasta, all unprocessed stuff. You will have to avoid convenience items. Asian markets are great for spices in bulk for cheap, but you don't have enough for that.

Stews/soups will help you stretch out components.

proof:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Born and raised a supreme poorfag, had many tough months (years).

Be ruthless at rationing, and do not eat more one day thinking you'll just skip eating a day or two. Very quickly you'll find you need to not eat for a week.

If you become hungry between meals, drink water. If you need energy, add sugar. Honey is better but not worth the cost. Yeah it sucks but it will keep you on your feet for VERY cheap. Coffee / tea has gotten very pricey where I live but of course that's great if you can get it cheaply where you're at but will not really give your body any energy, just keep away tiredness.

Oatmeal is fantastic if it's cheap. Add some cinnamon if you have it to make it less plain. Potatoes are also good but probably out of season and thus pricey if you are in the northern hemisphere. But not fresh is good too, look for frozen potato wedges or even fries. Rice and pasta goes without saying but I'd say oats + potatoes are preferable.

Get cheese. Cheapest you can find. Ration it. The fat will help you a lot. Buy multivitamin tablets. Disregard veggies. Not worth it with your budget. If you need to add variety to your meals, invest in spices instead.

For meat, well, hot dogs are generally the cheapest (assuming you won't eat offal / can't get a great deal on it from a butcher) and very fatty. Any highly processed "tube" meat really. Mince is also good, if only for added variety, but more pricey.
If you do go for tube meat, slice it and spice it. Will make it way more bearable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18755289
No seriously avoid that fake yixing stuff its 100% tainted or wont include yixing clay in the first place, ive never seen anyone have an issue with cheap porcelain but get a glazed one if you're in doubt
real yixing clay is really hard so it cannot be made using standard methods like slipcasting or with a jolly-jigger machine so it has to be slab built either by hand or with a half-handmade mold where after using the mold the spout and handle still have to be put on by hand. With the fake stuff they add things to the yixing clay or most likely its just some random clay where they try to make it look more like yixing and to make it usable with cheaper production methods.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18756252
>>18756257
google senchado
but basically, just use 2x more leaf per water than you normally would brewing western style. use a small teapot or teacup + strainer
first infusion / steeping around 1 to 1.5 minute, second should be much shorter at like 10-20 seconds, third is 30-45 seconds. use around 70 degrees celsius water for the first two brews, you can use hotter water later if you want to squeeze one or two more cups out of it
I think that's a decent start. of course feel free to adjust it to your liking

No one makes 100ml of tea though, that's not a helpful number. What we're actually dealing with is 6-8 oz (177-236ml) of water, or one mug. If you're using 180ml of water divide that by 60 (ml) for 3 g of tea.
However much water you're using / preferred strength = grams of tea to use

>>18758199
It's alright, depends on how much effort you put in and the post-brew flavoring process. I never experimented with different tea, I've seen some consensus that tea doesn't matter much but I'm sure it affects the flavor to some degree.
My advice, if you're concerned with "is it good" is to pay for some (overpriced, frankly) commercial Kombucha and see if you like it before you launch into actually brewing your own. If you get a plain flavor, you can keep a bit of the liquid and use it to start your culture. The more the better, so maybe pour half the bottle into a small glass and try it and then save the other half to start your first SCOBY (I used significantly less and had acceptable formation but it took way longer than I'd have liked)

posts.com:
Quick first impression tea notes:
2022 Purple Bud White Tea (250g)
https://www.liquidproust.com/listing/1372900063/2022-purple-bud-white-tea-250g

Parameters:
12.5g/100ml water @ 212F gongfu style with short steeps

Taste:
Strongly floral, dried bouquet
Pungent "floral musk" taste, not sure how to best describe it but if you drink fresh leafy green white teas you will recognize it
Fruity, watermelon rind, citrus peel
Somewhat drying, astringent
A pleasant bitterness that is a bit punchier than you would expect from many white teas
Quite spicy, unique peppery aftertaste, long lasting at the back of throat

Flavor wise a bit of a hybrid between more conventional white teas and yabao perhaps with some sheng like notes as well.

Conclusion:
Distinctly different than my other white teas, I like most of the flavor profile but I don't entirely like the peppery notes. Note a flavor I was looking for or expecting. Perhaps, the flavor profile will round out a bit more if I didn't overleaf it so much. Maybe a water lower temp would also be worth trying. The price on it is pretty good at only $20 for 250g. If you like white tea, want something new, and you don't mind the peppery notes I think you would like this. The taste is unique enough it stands out compared to more common white tea styles you may already own.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I use it, but many people don't understand how to.

A. It's a salt, so if you add it you have to reduce the regular salt, often people double up on salt because there was salt in a sauce they used or somthing.

B. It's a salt, so you add it last. People make the same mistake of adding it into something before they cook it down.

C. It's a salt, so you can easily saturate your palate if you add it to a sauce. You're adding MSG to every individual drop of sauce. Industrially MSG is often used as a powder.

D. Be sure there's no MSG in your food to begin with, it might be listed as E621 and there are several related analogues .
Some food is also MSG rich to begin with like fish sauce, soya sauce, tomato sauce, seaweed and parmesan.

You can usually buy chicken pretty cheap if you buy enough of it. Here the Aldi sells 2kg of chicken legs for $7 AUD or about $4.80 USD which you can cook in the oven and then add to meals which should keep you fed for 3-4 days, and you can use the bones for soup after too. Other than that rice and beans are good, tortillas are often pretty cheap too.
If you need to make a little more money do surveys and focus groups online. On some sites you'll never run out of surveys and while you won't make much, like $3-4 per hour, if you're seriously poorfagging it you'll take it. posts.com:
Just made my first espresso with my Christmas present to myself, a Wacaco Picopresso and a Kingrinder K4. For a first attempt from someone who doesn't know dick about espresso making, the result was actually quite nice. About as good as the average shot you'd get at a Starbucks; which I know to the aficionado might not be saying much, but for a novice like me, that was kind of the baseline of quality. Now comes the fun part, the next ten shots of espresso where I figure out the right grind setting, the right dosage amount, the right water ratio, the right extraction time, etc.

Incidentally, the K4 on Amazon US is relatively inexpensive. I don't remember if it's a clone of the 1Zpresso JX, JX-Pro, or J-Max, but it's currently sitting at $88 USD, about half the cost of a JX-Pro, and $11 cheaper than the Q2, which is the "entry level" 1Z model. I don't know if it's on sale, or if that's the new price, but it's way cheaper than the various guides and reviews online would suggest.
https://www.amazon.com/KINGrinder-Adjustable-Settings-Aeropress-Consistency/dp/B09WH4B91L

I know it'll sound like shilling, but I
just got a K4 as I mentioned, >>18755344 and immediately loved it. The results I got on the very first "test shot," which I was expecting to throw out so I can fine tune the variables, was so good that I didn't bother making a second one. The recommended setting that Kingrinder gives for espresso is 60 clicks, which was too fine, so I'd recommend doing maybe 58 or 62, whichever direction is coarser. The one gripe I do have with the K4, which isn't a dealbreaker, is that the zero point on the grinder out of the box is bullshit. There's a big 0 printed on the turning mechanism, but the actual zero point of the burrs is either plus or minus 5, depending on whether you go all the way open or all the way closed.

I've gone though over a dozen different grinders and coffee machines, and dozens of hipster specialty coffees... but always default back to 1kg bags of lavazza from walmart and my krups blade grinder in an aeropress using a scale.

Fuck specialty coffees, fuck expensive grinders, fuck coffee makers and espresso machines. I just want smooth, consistent, and strong coffee with zero acidity or bitterness that I can brew while my frying pan is heating up in the morning. It takes up minimal counter space, just a tiny corner beside my toaster and the only cleanup is dumping grounds and filter directly into the trash and a rinse.

Its just so consistent, so good at being perfectly average: it's the most boringly average cup of coffee I can make in 3 minutes directly in my cup.

>>18758784
> PSD charts for the grinder with various common burr sets involved
I don't think you understand what that would entail. When you see a particle distribution graph, its from a single coffee at a single burr gap at a single roast level at a single rpm at a random humidity, with an unknown alignment. Do you want the same coffee pulled at every single tickmark at every single rpm from 400-700 on every burr that fits on coffees of different roast levels of different origin, density, and processing method?
>anyone have actual PSD charts for some of the so-called "endgame" grinders
If you ask Denis from Kafatek about this he bans you from buying his grinders. Denis started machining his own burrs because of the random changes and inconsistencies from the burrs he was purchasing from ssp and mazzer.
>current setup is allegedly making about 33% fines
We're not doing this again. Buy a df64 and a random set off ssp and fuck off.
>>18758789
Its measuring the radial runout("wobble") of the shaft that rotates the burr. If your rotating burr carrier is wobbling in and out, its going to produce a different distribution than one that's not wobbling. One of the big criticisms of the Weber key is the long shaft thats more prone to wobble than the short one of on the wug. Hard to keep that wobble consistent from grinder to grinder when a random chinese factory is pumping out thousands of units for Breville or Oxo. That wobble is entirely separate from how parallel my burrs are aligned, or how consistent the burrs are to the set the graph you want was made off of. That's the video they sent of my actual unit. Looks to me like 0.012mm of wobble. Its literally 3 engineers in hong kong making the highest quality shit they can. I'm pretty sure kafatek is the same way, <5 guys in seattle cranking out units in small batches. I'd like to get my hands on some of their burrs but you have to have proof of ownership of a grinder to buy them.

I'll just tack these on. You can't taste a graph. It took trying a "high texture" bimodal conical(kinu) next to a "higher clarity" big set of flats(80mm lab sweet) to understand what people actually mean when they say clarity. I've still got nearly all the texture(syrupy, silky, smooth, slick shots), but its like someone cleaned the window I was looking out a bit. There's just way more focus on those blueberry bombs you're obsessed with. When you've got the adjustment to tweak your cup and really start cleaning up/isolating and chasing down that berry bomb note a little bit its amazing what other flavor notes are playing off of it. A shitty but relatable analogy would be how its hard to hear every musician on stage when you're standing right next to the speaker with your ears ringing. Pro tip to any anons here wanting to break free from wagie life with as little work as possible.
Scrape up 4700 dollars, not necessary but it makes life easier
Get a CDL-A
Get an Over the Road trucking job and live in your truck for about 5 years. Get your food stuffs from Walmart, you can always get a truck into Walmart. Get a cooker made for truckers. Buy water/drink of choice too
You CAN get internet on the road to shitpost/play vidya. Just spend a lil on a phone plan that gives you a mobile hotspot for a laptop, you're set.
Driving a truck pays fat cash, especially when you don't have to pay rent or a mortgage or send money home to a family. The driving part is best described like this: hours of boredom and seconds of terror. Just drive safe and stay alert and you will be alright.
If you cant get 4700 just find a company that will pay for your CDL training. They will force you to work for them for 6 months in exchange but you will still get paid, just not as much as a good company will. The more experience you get the more pay you can get.
DO. NOT. SIGN. A. LEASE.
Save your Loves/Flying J/Pilot fuel points to get free showers/drinks. Dont go to TA if you can help it.
If you have a gf/wife then dont do this. If you have kids, dont do this. This is for single guys with nothing but free time who want their fat stacks but have no real drive or ambition or talent.
If it works for me, it can work for anyone.
Disclaimer: i am not a boomer who did this 20 years ago. I did it two years ago. Its not paradise by a wide shot. But it is FAR better than ANY faggot retail job I ever had, EVER.

Dated a couple of mall hoes, shout out to the thots at Auntie Anne's

>>18759459
The average payout here looks to be about $1/km. If you really know how to play the system here, you can legally drive for 12.5h every 24h for 6 days a week. If it's just long-haul, full load to the destination at the end of that week, loaded and unloaded on your day off, you're still looking at a 70h cap (we have the option of 120h over a 14 day period, but it doesn't usually help). You're looking at an average speed of 75km/h, so... quickmath... It's possible to make about $5500 per week or $275k/a in Ontario, Canada, as a maximum. The average, working full tilt is probably more like $3000/wk / 150k/a because of deliveries, maintenance, construction, etc.

I thought about doing that, but then I found that logistics in the film industry can pay almost as well, and depending on what the day entails (if I have to remain on set), I can make $600/day (my absolute minimum is $300, usually low end is $450) to drop a truck and trailer off maybe an hour away, somewhere that a team of locations personnel has cleared and coned off for me. I've got all day to do maintenance, or a few more leisurely timed drops and pickups if I'm leaving set. If I wind up having to help the audio or video guys, I can charge an assistant fee on top (an extra $350)... and because I'm on time and useful, I've got a bunch of these guys scheming with me. If all goes well in the next year, I'll have a small fleet of all-in-one-ish trailers and some client-oriented video busses at my disposal, a dedicated vehicle return and maintenance crew, and I'll have to actually work for 13h a day, but I'll be pulling in $1500-ish a day 5 or 6 days a week, possibly with paid holidays.

Works at one of the busiest McDonalds in England, London Gatwick Airside.

Not only was it insanely busy with huge long queues but most of the passengers were stressed out, a large portion of which had food vouchers from their flights being delayed. Few people ever went full on rage as having patrolling police officers with semi-auto rifles tends to stop people going too far but most people you'd serve were grumpy.

Also, this conversation happened way too often

>"hi do you accept dollars?"
>"yes but we give an awful exchange rate and the change will be in pounds is that ok?"
>"sure"
>"ok, that meal is £2.99, in dollars that's $6.21"
>*customer hands over a $20 bill"
>"here's £5.12 in change"
>"What? That's way too expensive! And what am I going to do with pounds now?!?"

To make it extra fun there was pretty much impossible to do a refund for these.

Efficiency - automatically cleaned whenever you wash hands or shower.

Truly hygenic - you know where your cutlery has been.

Convenience - you have your eating utensils with you, literally at your fingertips. Never have anything stuck in your teeth with pinky nail toothpick.

Multi-use - small spoons can be used for consuming soup, snorting drugs, or precisely measuring out ingredients while cooking.

Attractive to those with a refined and efficient aesthetic.

Powerful self defense implements.

I could go on, but I think I've said enough.

I'm a big fan of Cantonese seafood recipes. My favorite way is probably a classic Cantonese steamed fish. One note on the recipe below, I do not recommend adding salt like they suggest the first time you make it. I think it's too salty with it it. https://thewoksoflife.com/steamed-whole-fish/ just make it with fillets if you can't handle the whole fish. I usually have to chop the head off and set it above the body so it'll fit in my steamer. Then I put them together when I plate the fish and nobody is any wiser to my ruse.

That website has a bunch of other good Chinese seafood recipes too, so browse around.

Other ways I like to eat seafood:
étouffée (I make it with shrimp, crawfish is a popular way to make it too)
sardines
fresh oysters

Because they don’t cook so they don’t know that when you use a sous vide you can go to a slightly higher temp because you don’t get the temp gradient you would by searing and then baking. When cooked the classic way it’s better to go on the lower side of the temp range to minimize the amount of loss to the temp band. No temp band, no need to go 125 on the temp. 135 is perfect when using a sous vide. I know this because I’ve been using one for over two years now and I’ve cooked countless steaks using it at this point. I know all the tips and tricks the books and videos wont teach you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I had absolutely horrible GERD for months. Antacids didn't work, omeprazole didn't work, and ranitidine didn't work. Not eating for days didn't work, eating a bland diet for weeks straight didn't work. It was all burn all the time, my esophagus would regularly get tight and spasm and the pain would radiate outwards. I had trouble sleeping because it was so bad.

Turned out it was because of one of the mental health drugs I was taking (I think it was Trintellix but it might have been something else) and as soon as I stopped taking it my GERD was almost immediately gone. The moral of the story is check for everything that might be causing it I guess. It seems wild now that I didn't make the connection between my new medication and severe GERD, but it never crossed my mind that the GERD started pretty soon after I started taking it.

posts.com: Well since there’s no /wg/ I’ll just post this here. I managed to grab this baby today and already popped it open and holy mother of eternal flames this baby sets you on fucking fire. You know how you get different kinds of drunk from different liquors; you have the happy kind, the zen kind, the serious kind… well this one just makes me feel fucking alive. I know Glenfiddich can be a bit of a meme and they’ve been fucking around with 40% ABV bullshit for some time now… but this sucker at 50.2%… holy shit. Glenfiddich really do know how to make a seriously good scotch when they aren’t being held back by their fucking bean counters. I’m so glad I picked this bottle up and given them a chance on this one. This is easily 95/100 material for me, possibly even higher. It’s going to take me a while to settle on a final score but this is definitely right up there as one of the best whisky’s I’ve ever had and I’m honoured to have opened it on this day. Unfortunately Glenfiddich in their typical stubbornness aren’t making this easily obtainable. It’s only available at the duty free at an airport in my country. Fucking hell.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18756412
For whisky I generally find that the ABV going up brings out more of the flavours, especially flavours which tend to linger at the back. Glenfiddich for me has always been more fruity with hardly any peat and not that much oak. And while I do still appreciate the Glenfiddich 18 40% as it’s really a decent bottle it’s also kinda annoying that I often feel that the flavours could be exposed a little more, because there’s really a lot going on. I agree with you though that one sign of a good liquor is having a silly high ABV while not actually tasting any of the alcohol, which Glenfiddich knows how to master. So it’s somewhat aggravating that they’re purposefully nerfing themselves. I don’t think anyone really knows why but the rumour is that they just want to get more bottles out. Glenfiddich has also been doing this thing where they’ll do restricted releases of higher ABV bottles like the one I just acquired (it’s pretty much limited to duty free merchants at airports and only in select countries). And from what I heard the original 18 43% can still be acquired but only at their distillery. It’s bloody annoying because they know their shit. The 15 VAT 03 50.2% I got was only about 80US$ and alcohol taxes in my country are stupid high. So they also know how to release a fucking stupid good product at a very decent price. Yeah. Go figure. I both love and hate Glenfiddich, but at least I managed to get one bottle of the VAT 03 and I’ll enjoy every last drop of it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: Is a Tojiro DP even worth upgrading from?
posts.com:
I know people get absolutely anal about knives. But realistically, it's a simple tool. Sharp steel used to cut things. You look for characteristics you like based on your needs and personal preference.

As far as I'm concerned, I just want a simple chef's knife. I want the blade to be tall enough so that I don't cut my fingers off (I pinch grip). I don't like Wa style handles. I don't like rectangular profile handles. I don't like bolsters.

I currently use a Victorinox Fibrox 8" chef's knife.

So the Tojiro DP seems like a good option. The Wusthof Classic Ikon seems like a perfect knife to me, but it's more expensive, I think VG-10 is a better steel and while the ergonomic handle looks like a dream, the blade looks very meh and plain. That's not important, but with the Tojiro being way cheaper, it just makes sense to my head.

It's also got me thinking, with a knife like the Tojiro, is it ever worth getting a more expensive knife from a pragmatic standpoint? I can't think if a good reason besides "it may look prettier." You'd probably get peanuts in return in terms of performance for your dollar.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I finally quit after 12 years of nicotine use and I feel completely fine. It was only hell for about a week, and then there were 2 more weeks of constantly thinking about nicotine and having to be sad that I couldn't have anymore. But now it's been a month and I'm completely over it, no more withdrawal symptoms, no more cravings, just feel 100% fine and normal. Except I don't need to keep consuming nicotine in order to be comfortable. I basically can just be comfortable indefinitely. It feels like there's a magical nicotine patch inserted inside my skin and it never runs out, so it just keeps feeding me pleasure and keeping me feeling content. I had no idea I could be like this. It's really awesome.

I always thought that if I quit, my life would basically be hell forever, since I'd always have to keep missing nicotine every day for the rest of my life. I thought it would be like having a wife tragically killed in a car accident and then you always miss her forever. I thought that even though the physical withdrawal could obviously go away, and chemically my brain would go back to normal, I'd never be able to forget the knowledge of how much I love smoking and dipping. I thought since I ate the forbidden fruit of knowledge, I was doomed to nicotine slavery forever.

I just can't express to you guys how fucking crazy it is that the feeling of missing cigarettes and feeling down and "lonely" about quitting, it literally just went away in under a month. I can't believe it was that fucking easy all along, and I just never stuck it out long enough to find this out sooner. I have been an addict for 12 fucking years and wishing I could stop for most of that time. And all along I literally could.

>>18747625
Nicaraguan cigars are as good or better than Cuban cigars and have been for a while.
When Castro took over, some tobacco growers took their best seeds and traveled around Latin America looking for the ideal location to replant: Nicaragua. Nicaraguan cigars aren’t as prestigious as Cubans, but they’re as good or better for a fraction of the cost, not to mention that it’s very hard to get Cubans in some countries.
Fun fact: A few years ago, Cuban tobacco was devastated by a hurricane, so the producers went abroad in search of the best seed: Nicaragua. So, the Cubans you’re smoking today were likely grown from Nicaraguan seed.

Technique and timing MATTER. Someone who salts their meat after they cook it will have a vastly different product to someone who salts it before, or even the night before, cooking. Same with seasoning.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18758720
1. The rice better be short grain rice, or you are fucked.
2. They add stuff to the rice to make it sticky, usually some mixture involving rice wine and other stuff. Look it up.
3. Sushi rolling mat - add cling film to wrap it
4. Nori sheet goes down first, cut to size
5. Rice - paddle it onto the nori
6. Spread the rice into a thin layer over nori
7. In a line, add your fillings (away from edges)
8. Add sauces, don't use soy, that won't work. Use jap mayo base and add stuff to it. Or use a thick teriyaki.
9. Roll, move the mat out of the way, then finish the roll, tuck and squeeze.
10. Cover roll in cling film, then wet sharp knife and cut into pieces through the film

Soy goes in the dipping dish. Do no use in replacement for a sauce.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18759037
Your rice is way too wet. Use less water, sushi rice should be cooked firmly.

Roll slowly and firmly. Don’t be afraid to press down. Make sure your apply pressure to the roll from center to edge. Basically just stroke the roll horizontally.

Don’t press down on the rice too hard when you have it flat. You want to firm up the roll while rolling. Leaving fluff allows the rice to naturally fall into the right shape when you are rolling

>>18762603
Yes.
But not at an alarming rate and possibly only depending on production/breeding/raising/husbandry methods that were not controlled for.

It is possible that grass-fed beef does not.
It is also possible that beef without Pre-maturity hormone treatments do/do not compared to other options, and so on and so forth.

For now, it has been established that red meat causes cancer, but details are still being worked out. It may take a few decades to figure out the details.

Also, Even though red meat is classified as cancer-causing (in the same category, for this purpose, as cigarettes) BUT it is important to also realize that just because it has been established that both cigarettes and beef cause cancer, that it does not also mean that they do so at the same rates or degrees of severity or same varieties of cancer.

Beef causes fewer forms of cancer, at MUCH lower rates, and, it would seem, with lesser severity as well (Although this has not really been explored much). So, if someone says eating beef is as bad as smoking cigarettes, they are just wrong. If they simply claim that research shows that beef causes cancer, that's true, but many details or not known currently.

Also, some people refuses to trust European research on this for some odd reason, so that's an issue to in both the denial camp and the vegan camp depending on what few articles they choose to use as examples.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18703613
I don't like:

1) Processed cheese. Anyone who puts processsed cheese on a burger should get a firing squad. Unless you're a wagie at a fast food place, there are no excuses for doing this shit, ever.

2) Fried eggs. The sulfur taste of the yolk and the texture of the eggs clashes with the rest. If you made a thin omelette and folded it and put it on the burger that could work for a breakfast burger, but that's about the only reason I can think of.

3) Olives, marinated artichokes or pickled peppers: They're fucking great, especially in sandwiches, but they're too wet and don't pair well with other ingredients.

4) Any kind of weird shit mixed into the ground beef used to make the burger patties. The beef should contain only beef, and perhaps salt. MAYBE you can add black pepper. MAYBE. If the beef is getting old then crust it in garlic powder to mask the taste a bit, but that's only if the beef is on the edge of inedible. Don't drown it in a ton of butter or oil. Put the patties in a little oil to start with, but let them cook in their own fat.

5) Non-western spices/ingredients. Anyone who adds weird goop like gookchang should be given a free helicopter ride.

6) Excessive grease or sauce. I don't like a slimy burger, fuck off with that shit.

7) Fake meat. I don't need to say anything else.
A burger can contain any kind of meat, but it should have meat. Not sure what to call Portobello burgers.

8) Foods which are generally incompatible with the structure of a burger, or which don't pair with burgers well. Overly sweet things, for example. So, no donuts or strudels.

I can't think of anything else, is that a good list?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When I started making burgers at home I realised how little you actually need to make a good burger.
Lots of toppings just overcrowds a burger, makes it sloppy and unstable, you honestly just need 1 strongly flavoured topping.
My top is:
- jalapenos
- pickles (salt ones not vinegar)
- olives (green)
- NO KETCHUP, literally anything is better, I usually like weird shit like remoulade, but even mayo or a generic burger sauce is better than ketchup.
I don't even use cheese sometimes because i can't even taste it in the burger. Unless i use something strong. Irish cheddar actually worked well.
I should try to make the OG too, mustard, onions and meat. That's it. Should be tasty.

posts.com:
Add mustard, cook on high heat. The extra emulsifying component helps it to retain moisture so you can cook hot without making a mess.
Similarly, add your butter as a chunk after the eggs are in the pan and emulsify it in. Better result than just mixing in melted butter.
I always add garlic powder, and serve it over toast with onion/tomato chutney, but those are just my preferences.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18761358
There are a handful of ways to spice up a scramble. Prior to scrambling the eggs you can add any of the following:
1. chopped onions
2. chopped peppers
3. cubed ham
4. cubed potato
5. chopped bacon
6. cubed tomato

Additionally, during the last bit of the scramble you can add:
1. cheese (cheddar works well)
2. chopped chive
3. chopped parsley

Ground pepper and any other ground seasonings should be added at the end so they are on the surface for tasting with the egg.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18761535
(cont)
Sausage bits are also things you can add, forgot about that. Both bacon and sausage need to be precooked before the scramble. Use the fat combined with butter for the egg scramble part for extra flavor.

Scrambled egg with stuff wrapped in a soft burrito or taco shell makes breakfast tacos.

It is also advisable to serve a potato product with eggs, they pair super well. Hash browns, tots, whatever floats your boat.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18761358
For scrambled eggs, I break the eggs then salt then and let them sit for 15 minutes or so. You'll see the color change a little bit. After that, I mix in a bit of heavy cream and carbonated water, it makes it more fluffy. Then I put some butter in it plus whatever seasoning and cook them. I constantly move the spatula until they start to curd and aren't as wet. After that I top them with chives and sharp white cheddar.

posts.com: For me, it's adding a small bit of milk or half and half then whipping with salt and pepper, then into the pan with pieces of solid butter, stirring on an easy heat so the butter gets emulsified in then stirring relatively continuously so it all finishes at the same time without giant chunks anywhere

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18761358

Don't use non-stick. IMO scrambled tastes better when cooked at higher heat for a very short amount of time rather than low and slow.

In a stainless pan, let the pan fully heat on medium low, add half vegetable oil half butter, and heat to shimmering. Two beaten eggs in, don't touch for 3~5 seconds to let the egg set, then a couple folds, then eggs out. The whole thing should be cooked in under 15 seconds. Add salt and pepper after.

>put cheese grater in freezer
>heat pan over medium heat
>couple teaspoons of olive oil in pan
>crack eggs into bowl
>season with black pepper and chives
>whisk together
>retrieve cold cheese grater from freezer
>retrieve cold butter from fridge
>grate cold butter into eggs on fine side of grater
>whisk butter into egg mixture
>pour eggs into hot pan
The butter will melt inside the egg as it cooks making them fluffy and creamy, and less butter will be wasted than if you just added the butter straight to the pan.

>>18746943
County of origin, type of sugar cane byproduct used (cane juice, sugar, molasses, other), still used (pot, column, both) and aging are the most important factors. Good luck finding most of that out with your average rum. Agricole is a legal term and usually means cane juice and a vegetal and herbal flavor. Age means little because it's so hot in the tropics and some of the barrel houses are at high altitude.

The real scientific hangover cure is:

Water, can include electrolyte sachet
Eat a whole raw yellow grapefruit or drink half a litre of no added sugar grapefruit juice slowly(Not pink grapefruit)
A slice of toast with peanut butter
Wait a short while and drink a strong coffee
10mins of exercise

Theory is; Water to rehydrate, Yellow grapefruit contains lots of amino acids that your liver uses to remove alcohol from your bloodstream. Toast has slow burning energy to fuel the process and peanut butter contains lots of Iron that your liver and kidneys need to replenish for optimal function. Once your liver is loaded with amino acids, down a strong coffee to increase bloodflow, exercise to increase your heart rate to cycle the blood through your liver while the Amino acids are working.
US Military used this for a long time as the beginning of their 3day diet for people who got fat during breaks between deployment.

>Also is it true that in Burgerland you can only get sushi from sit down resturaunts and grocery stores? In Australia ‘fast food’ sushi is everywhere, you just pick what you want from the display and walk off.
(Checked.) That sounds nice. I think it's fair to say that sit-down restaurants and supermarkets are the norm, along with sometimes convenience stores (like at petrol stations). In large urban areas you might (MIGHT) find a Japanese food truck to sushi to-go.


But there is a special category of restaurants worth mentioning: all-you-can-eat Asian buffets. Some are "Chinese", some are "hibachi", they all have a wide selection "American Chinese" sloppa alongside normal American buffet fare... but often also sushi and even sashimi. Of course it's not the same as a proper Japanese restaurant, and the selection is limited. (Lots of California rolls, salmon, tuna, imitation crab. Not so much eel.) But it's usually a little fresher than than supermarket sushi, and you can eat 40 pieces if you're so inclined for like $10-15.

(To be fair, pic related is from an article called "Why You Shouldn't Touch the Sushi at All-You-Can-Eat Buffets", citing concerns about temperature control. But if you visit during peak hours, it's usually not sitting around for very long.)

"Sushi" runs the gamut from bland to spicy as fuck. Just depends on the item being ordered and what the chef shoved in it. The main problem with sushi is you get what you pay for: knock off buffet shit is fucking terrible, middle tier can run the gamut from terrible to great, and high end can be either fantastic or weird. So it is totally possible to have shit experiences with the food, souring newcomers. Conveyor sushi (at least in America) is usually trash tier compared to sit down places. Same with buffet sushi (it is always terrible).

Some stuff is definitely weird and not worth the expense: octopus, squid, the yellow shit I am blanking on the name of right now. However, things like the smoked salmon and bbq eel are delightful and worth their price. There are other fish cuts that taste fantastic, and wagu beef that has been seared is also great (I had it in Australia). I personally love the flavors of certain raw fish over others, but I do get how it isn't for everyone. The rolls are nice too.

But yea, $50 for a meal is fucking expensive as fuck. But high end fish comes with a high end price tag. I've paid $40/lb for King Salmon fresh from the market, so I do get why it comes with a hefty tag at the shop.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18752376
>anyone who makes sushi knows a safe way to deal with raw fish?

I've been eating raw fish at home for about 4 years now. there are 2 main risks with raw fish:

>parasites
do your research to learn which fish carry the highest risk, but in general, anything that spends time in fresh water can have parasites, while fish that live exclusively in saltwater rarely have parasites. So if you want to eat raw salmon, it's best to freeze it to a temperature and for a time that will kill any parasites. Most places selling "sashimi grade" salmon use that term to indicate it's been frozen properly to eliminate any parasites. Again, do your research here, because freezing to eliminate parasites works the same as pasteurization: you need to hit a target temperature for a set amount of time. Your home freezer may not get cold enough to practically do this.

>salmonella
Salmonella lives in the guts of fish. So when the fish is gutted, if the knife that opens the belly pierces the guts AND pierces the meat, then the meat is contaminated. The only protection you have is to trust your source of fish not to contaminate their product. If you don't trust them, your options are either to cook the fish (this kills the salmonella) or catch your own damn fish and process it yourself. Plenty of reputable places online will ship sashimi-grade, salmonella-free fish to your door. So if you don't trust anyone local, try Fulton, Riviera, or somewhere else.

posts.com:
TL;DR: First make a starch-thickened sauce/pudding without yolks, let cool down a little, then add yolks, bring back to a simmer, and you're done.

Upsides to this method:
• No risk of the hollandaise breaking, splitting, separating, or scrambling.
• Less dirty dishes thanks to not needing a double boiler or an extra bowl.
• Allows for a higher proportion of egg yolks to butter if you desire.
• Can cook the whole thing with high heat if you wanted without worrying about eggs curdling.
• Thickness of the sauce can be adjusted to your liking.
• Basically faster and more foolproof overall.

Downsides to this method:
• Don't know. You tell me if you can think of one.

Procedure:
The basic idea is that the base of the sauce is a simple pudding-like sauce made of a bit of water or milk and some kind of starch like cornstarch, potato starch, rice flour, and so on, which prepares it for the yolks later.

1. Leave egg yolks aside and mix everything else (water/milk, starch, anything else you like besides the yolks) together in a saucepan and heat on the stove, stirring constantly until you reach a boil or the starch gels and the mixture thickens, then turn off heat. If the sauce isn't thickened after reaching a simmer, the egg yolks may curdle in the later steps, so add more slurry as needed until you achieve a thick sauce.
2. Let the sauce cool down in the pan off the heat for a minute or two, or until just not hot enough to scramble the egg yolks. Stirring the sauce around constantly at this point helps it cool down faster.
3. Once the sauce/pudding is still warm but not too hot to cause scrambled eggs (cool enough that if you dipped your fingertip into the sauce it won't hurt), add yolks.
4. Place saucepan back on heat and resume stirring constantly until the sauce reaches a simmer once more so the egg yolks have cooked (at least 165ºF).
5. Enjoy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18760856

Notes:
- Because this sauce is first thickened with gelatinized starch, the yolks won't scramble or curdle even if you bring the sauce to a full boil. Example of this phenomenon (but with cheese instead of yolks): 13:36 https://youtu.be/10lXPzbRoU0?t=816
- For step 1, you may use wheat flour instead and begin by making a roux, then proceeding with the rest of the recipe the same way. If using a non-wheat starch like potato, cornstarch, or rice flour, it helps to have a slurry handy to adjust the thickness of the sauce as you go.
- You can add the butter or fat at any point during step 1; personally I like to add it at the beginning before the heat.
- Obviously season to taste and add anything you want in the hollandaise like hot sauce, herbs, spices, lemon juice, vinegar, whatever.
- I deliberately left out ingredient amounts and proportions. The key to this method is starting out by making a pudding. The starch to liquid ratio is the main thing that affects the final thickness of the sauce, but this can be adjusted as you go with slurry. Every starch has different thickening power depending so look up starch you're using before you start the recipe.
- Yes I know about the blender + hot butter method. That method works but still sucks dick and who the fuck wants to bring out a whole ass blender just to make a sauce then clean it afterwards. Also you can't use a higher proportion of egg yolks with that method like you can with this one.

1/2 cup heavy cream
4 large egg yolks
1 1/2 Tbsp lemon juice
1 tsp dijon mustard (optional)
1 - 2 pinches cayenne pepper (optional)
1/2 cup unsalted butter, melted
Salt and freshly ground black pepper

Heavy cream makes it a little lighter but still delicious.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18748475
Trans Canada Brewing in Winnipeg
Rebellion Brewing in Regina
Haven't been to any breweries in Ontario that really blew me away but most of them are alright. Best I've been to was probably Tooth and Nail Brewing in Ottawa. The waitress also wasn't wearing a bra and there was a nice bakery across the road.
In Quebec, Frontibus and Naufrager in Gaspesie both make some great beers. Fin du Monde also comes in tallboys in Quebec and you can buy them for 4$ at grocery stores. Probably my favourite beer province not so much for going to breweries but almost all the beer is good and you can buy it anywhere.
Only been to one brewery in New Brunswick, Four Rivers in Bathurst. It was okay but nothing special, which is kind of the impression I've gotten of most NB beers.
Only been to PEI Brewing on PEI. Nothing special.
In Nova Scotia, the best brewery I went to was 2 Crows in Halifax, but I think most of the beer I had from Halifax breweries was pretty good. Schoolhouse Brewery in Windsor was pretty good too.
All the breweries I've visited in Alberta have been kind of eh, but I'm sure there's a good one out there. I had a rye beer from Medicine Hat Brewing which was alright.
In the Yukon, Winterlong is probably the most consistently good but Woodcutters Blanket has made some okay beers and Polarity does some good ones too. Yukon Brewing has been on a downward trend in quality the last three years.
Haven't had any beer from NWT, Nunavut or Newfoundland.
Another of my favourite breweries in BC is Backroads Brewing in Nelson. Also like Category 12 in Saanichton and Driftwood in Victoria (pic related is one of my all time favourite beers).

Pile'O'Bones (SK), Unibroue (QC), Fuggles & Warlock (BC), and Grizzly Paw (AB) are my favorite Canadian breweries.

I'm pretty much only familiar with SK/AB/BC/YT beer as I've lived in all four locations for a time. I find Rebellion mediocre for SK breweries. Pile'O'Bones, Nokomis, 9 Mile, Malty National, and Bushwakker are all better. I think I have tried every brewery in SK, and those are the best ones and they are very good. For a fairly small province SK has remarkably good food and drink.

YT is small enough that I tried everything and nothing was memorable.

AB I haven't delved into that hard. Everything from Calgary was bad. Grizzly Paw from Canmore is very good, especially on tap. Jasper Brewing I have only had on tap and it was consistently good, but nothing stellar.

The BC beer scene is far more diverse than SK but overwhelmingly disappointing. I've had Dageraad, Strange Fellows, Tailout, Phillips, Hoyne, Lighthouse, Townsite, Persephone, Whistler Brewing, Fuggles & Warlock, Torchlight, Nelson Brewing, Granville Island, Over Time, Grist & Mash, Fernie Brewing, Arrowhead, Whitetooth, Mt. Begbie, Field House, and a bunch of others that I can't even remember. Most of these I have had beer on tap at the breweries themselves.

Fuggles&Warlock and Dageraad are best overall BC breweries.
Field House has one standout blackberry/blueberry sour.
Fernie Brewing has one standout seasonal pumpkin ale.
Whistler has one standout seasonal winter dunkel (sweet orange&spice dessert beer).
Granville Island has a night light summer raspberry ale.
The rest are forgettable and can't even do a good basic brown, amber, etc.

Cider is a type of beverage made from the fermented juice of apples. In the United States, cider is often used to refer specifically to a type of sweet, unfiltered apple juice that is made from crushed apples and is often consumed as a non-alcoholic beverage. The term "cider" is also sometimes used to refer to a type of alcoholic beverage made from fermented apple juice, which is similar to but stronger than regular cider. This type of cider is often referred to as "hard cider" to distinguish it from non-alcoholic cider. In other parts of the world, the term "cider" is more commonly used to refer to alcoholic cider, while non-alcoholic apple juice is referred to as simply "apple juice."

Pizza is a highly subjective food, and different people have different tastes and preferences. Some people may prefer the thin, crisp crust and simple toppings of New York-style pizza, while others may prefer the thicker, softer crust and more complex toppings of Detroit-style pizza. There is no one "best" style of pizza - it's all a matter of personal taste. That being said, it's perfectly okay to have your own opinions and preferences when it comes to food. If you think Detroit-style pizza is the best, then that's your opinion and it's perfectly valid.

>>18754238
It's true that different regions of the world have their own unique styles of pizza, and many people may not have had the opportunity to try all of them. Pizza is a global food, and there are many different variations to be found around the world, each with its own unique characteristics and flavors. The Okanagan region of British Columbia is known for its fresh, locally sourced ingredients, and it's possible that wood-fired pizza made with these ingredients could be delicious. It's always interesting to try new foods and discover new flavors and culinary traditions from different parts of the world.

>NEW YORK, Dec 29 (Reuters) - Hershey Co (HSY.N) has been sued by a consumer who accused the company of selling dark chocolate that contains harmful levels of lead and cadmium. In a proposed class action filed on Wednesday, Christopher Lazazzaro said he would not have bought or would have paid less for Hershey's Special Dark Mildly Sweet Chocolate, Lily's Extra Dark Chocolate 70% Cocoa and Lily's Extreme Dark Chocolate 85% Cocoa had Hershey disclosed their metals content.

>Hershey did not immediately respond on Thursday to requests for comment on the lawsuit, which was filed in the federal court in Central Islip, New York. Lazazzaro, a resident of Nassau County, New York, sued two weeks after Consumer Reports unveiled the results of scientific testing of 28 dark chocolate bars for lead and cadmium. Hershey's Special Dark bar and Lily's 70% bar were high in lead, and Lily's 85% bar was high in lead and cadmium, the magazine said. Lazazzaro said reasonable consumers would be turned off by such levels because they pose a "serious health risk," and that consumers rely on Hershey to be truthful about ingredients in its products.

>The lawsuit seeks at least $5 million of damages, including at least $500 per transaction under New York law. Hershey bought Lily's for $425 million in June 2021. The case is Lazazzaro v Hershey Co, U.S. District Court, Eastern District of New York, No. 22-07923.

There's a CR petition you can sign to prod for supply chain reform:

>>18754605
>I only eat white chocolate so I'm not worried.
Actually not a bad idea since the bio-accumulation occurs in the cocoa solids not the cocoa butter.

>>18759253
>okay so there's some heavy metals in milk chocolate then. So should we avoid chocolate altogether then?
Leveling with you: Pretty much unless you are an extreme chocoholic in the next few years as manufactures try to reduce their content in the beans.
https://www.npr.org/2022/12/17/1143239430/dark-chocolate-lead-cadmium-consumer-reports
>Johns Hopkins Medicine toxicologist Andrew Stolbach told NPR that maximum allowable dose levels are set to be "very conservative" to account for people with higher risk due to their age and other medical conditions. When the chocolate is consumed in moderate amounts, the lead and cadmium levels are nothing to worry about, he says. "If you make sure that the rest of your diet is good and sufficient in calcium and iron, you protect yourself even more by preventing absorption of some lead and cadmium in your diet."

I've always thought the "Moderation" assurance was conferring false security as if we aren't an over-indulgent nation of consoomers. Asbestos exposure is probably okay too "in moderation". There's no real safe level of heavy metal contamination for humans and the level of danger is dose-dependent. Milk chocolate tends to only have 30-40% Max Cocoa Solids (as they are mostly sugar with a sprinkling of milk solids) so the level of possible heavy metals in them be less than any semi-sweet or dark varieties. Cocoa Powder is 100% solids so prolly shy away from that.

>>18751912
>it doesn't come from the processing the shit comes from the ground
Only the cadmium is soil-originated, the lead is introduced during the post-harvest process (drying and fermenting the beans).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18761002

That only works with a reverse seared steak.

By getting the steak's core temp up to 55c in an oven and then searing it with a cast iron or stainless pan, the target dT is low, so you can very quickly build a crust and bring the internal temp to 60c without the grey rings caused by trying to overcome large dT that is found in the traditional stainless cooktop method.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18760869
>>18761002

Ok my advice is the following cooking method:

>take steak out of fridge 20-60 mins before cooking
>high heat pan
>rub steak in oil, salt, and other spices
>put in high heat pan, sear both sides and edges
>take off and let rest
>lower the heat in pan. Once it's cooler, add butter, garlic, thyme, rosmary, shallots...whatever you want, even just garlic is fine.
>put steak back in lower heated pan, baste with butter
>cook until just before desired doneness
>let rest
wala

Cons:
takes a little longer

Pros:
Almost impossible to fuck up
Room for error when cooking on low, you don't have to worry that 10 seconds too long will make it tough
You don't burn the shit out of your butter or garlic
Can use a thermometer to be precise but don't need to
Believe it or not, the low heat and butter will continue to develop the crust

It will taste delicious, and you will not need disgusting corn syrup steak sauce

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It is not appropriate to punish a child for not wanting to eat a particular food or for not liking a particular sauce. Children's tastes and preferences can change over time, and it is important to respect their individual preferences and allow them to make their own food choices to the extent possible.

Instead of punishing your daughter for not wanting to eat your Quinky Sauce, you could try offering her a variety of different condiments and sauces to choose from, or allow her to customize her own burger with the toppings and condiments that she prefers. You could also try offering a variety of different foods and meals to ensure that there is something that she enjoys eating.

It is also important to remember that children's nutritional needs are different from those of adults, and it is important to offer a balanced and varied diet that meets their specific needs. If you are concerned about your daughter's nutrition, you may want to consider consulting with a healthcare professional or a registered dietitian for advice.
